subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception ?

messageBody:
Mike Duffy wrote:
> I agree with the point that listing all the possible exceptions
> greatly increases code maintenance. The goal was to know what
> exception was thrown if the specific exception being tested is not
> thrown (without having to go to a stack trace). This goal can be
> accomplished by catching Exception with a fail in the catch block and
> including the name of the exception in the fail message.

Mike,

I agree with what you are trying to do, but I disagree violently to how you
are trying to accomplish it.

The problem with your pattern is that, while you know the name of the
exception, you've lost all other information. You have no way of knowing
from the output which line in the test caused the exception or which line in
the code actually threw the exception. In order to find out this
information, you either have to use a debugger or modify the test. 9 times
out of 10, the stack trace is more useful than the mere knowledge of what
exception was actually thrown (which you don't lose anyway...

All this information is available in the framework already. All you need to
do is modify the TestRunner, or use a different one. For example, if you run
your unit tests from an Ant script, you will find that the TestRunner
provided by Ant provides the class name, the message, and the stack trace.

Robert.
